JobPositionInformation.Purpose:
Applications are invited for a PhD fellowship/scholarship at Graduate School of Technical Sciences, Aarhus University, Denmark, within the Agroecology programme. The position is available from 01 November 2022 or later.

Title:
PhD in Greenhouse Gas Emissions

Research area and project description:
The agricultural sector is responsible for 23% of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in Denmark, and the Danish Climate Act mandates net-zero GHG emissions by 2050. Especially the reduction of CO2 and nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions is paramount to reach this goal. Understanding the driving factors of CO2 and N2O production in agricultural soils can help to understand the source of GHG emissions, and how to reduce GHG during crop production.

The PhD candidate’s objective is to increase our understanding of GHG emission processes in agricultural soils in Denmark. Trials will be conducted and aligned to the Klimagræs project (Grant No. 33010-NIFA-19-708) with the objective to quantify GHGs among crop management schemes, and to understand the impact of soil-plant-atmosphere interactions on GHGs in agricultural mineral soils. Therefore, GHG measurements will be conducted in conjunction with measurements of explanatory soil chemical and physical parameters for two cropping seasons. The derived datasets will be used to predict and explain GHG emissions with empirical and/or process-based modelling approaches. The PhD project is funded by the Novo Nordisk Foundation NNF21OC0072838.

Project description. For technical reasons, you must upload a project description. Please simply copy the project description above, and upload it as a PDF in the application.

Qualifications and specific competences:
The applicants must have a M.S. degree in Soil Science, Agronomy, Environmental Science or closely related fields. Demonstrated excellent oral and written communication skills in English are required. Basic knowledge of greenhouse gas measurements and/or modelling is of advantage, but not required. The applicant will have the opportunity to present on conferences and publish in peer-reviewed journals. The applicant should be enthusiastic about working in an international and interdisciplinary academic environment. Applications from women and people from underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged.

Place of employment and place of work:
The place of employment is Aarhus University, and the place of work is Department of Agroecology – Soil Fertility Section, Research Centre Foulum, Blichers Allé 20, 8830 Tjele, Denmark.

Contacts:
Applicants seeking further information are invited to contact:
  • Researcher Christian Dold, c.dold@agro.au.dk
  • Senior Scientist Jørgen Eriksen, jorgen.eriksen@agro.au.dk
How to apply:
Please follow this link to submit your application. Application deadline is 31 May 23:59 .

Preferred starting date is 01 November 2022.

For information about application requirements and mandatory attachments, please see our application guide.
Please note:
  • The programme committee may request further information or invite the applicant to attend an interview.
  • Shortlisting will be used, which means that the evaluation committee only will evaluate the most relevant applications.

Aarhus University’s ambition is to be an attractive and inspiring workplace for all and to foster a culture in which each individual has opportunities to thrive, achieve and develop. We view equality and diversity as assets, and we welcome all applicants. All interested candidates are encouraged to apply, regardless of their personal background. Salary and terms of employment are in accordance with applicable collective agreement.
